comments.author: bullrun2024bro
comments.body: Quote from: cygan on October 10, 2023, 05:02:40 PMdas kann ich dir leider auch nicht klar sagen. aber das blocktrainer team hat das ganze nun mehr oder weniger √ºber die lupe genommen und hat einen doch sehr informativen dt. artikel √ºber das bitvm ver√∂ffentlicht.Danke dir f√ºr die Blocktrainer-Verlinkung @cygan. Ich war heute auch noch ein wenig aktiv und hab viel zum Thema gelesen. Sehr komplexe Geschichte und BitVM scheint auch nicht die Patentl√∂sung zu sein, zu der sie in den sozialen Medien teilweise schon hochgejubelt wurde.Ein Beitrag der das ganze zusammenfasst, ist mMn dieser hier. Auch mit einem TL;DR, falls man nicht alles lesen m√∂chte. Ansonsten einfach in den Twitter-Post schauen. Dort findet man noch viele Kommentare und Hinweise zum Thema.QuoteBitVM: Everything you need to know (and more...)BitVM is a new Optimistic Roll Up + Fraud Proof + Taproot Leaf + Bitcoin Script computing paradigm designed by Robin Linus at Zero Sync. They published an excellent white paper this morning reviewed by Super Testnet and Sam Parker (post currently has 1.5M views!)tl;dr1. This is not a silver bullet solution2. No, BitVM is not as good as EVM, BitVM is slower, more expensive, and more complex3. The core benefit of BitVM is we get additional programmability right now on Bitcoin without an upgrade. No new op_codes needed. No soft fork needed. Ready to go right now.4. Easy potential use cases include decentralizing various parts of applications that currently rely on centralized services (DLC oracles, congestion control/coinjoin aggregators, sidechain quorums)5. No, BitVM doesn‚Äôt solve trustless bridging for sidechains (likely requires covenants)6. Yes, BitVM is strictly better than Greg Maxwell‚Äôs 2016 ZKP contingent payments example7. BitVM is VERY complex to understand and implement. Upgrading Bitcoin with an op_code could accomplish the same thing.Technical Deep DiveAlright, now let‚Äôs dig into the technical side of things. I am heavily quoting many others throughout my summary here because it was the safest way to stay true to what they said without misquoting them.BitVM‚Äôs purpose is ‚Äúany computable function can be verified on Bitcoin." - BitVM whitepaperWhich means that ‚ÄúBitcoin is now as Turing Complete as any other chain, and this requires zero changes to Bitcoin‚Äù - Sam ParkerThere are limitations (which we will get to later), but essentially what this means is as long as you: (1) have enough money to pay for off-chain computation/proofs, (2) have bandwidth to receive and send the necessary data (could be 100s of MB), and (3) can do as many Bitcoin transactions as needed, THEN you can compute anything you want."All BitVM does is allow us to split the runtime of some logic that would be out of bounds of a single transaction across multiple transactions. That‚Äôs it." - Sam ParkerSo it might take a REALLY long time. And it might be REALLY expensive. And it might take hundreds of transactions. But you can do whatever you want. üòÄReiterated by Sam himself: "So Bitcoin really isn‚Äôt any more Turing Complete by the technical definition as it was before, it simply has been given a runtime to its programs that we can reasonably say it‚Äôs ‚ÄúTuring complete enough‚Äù for any program that we could realistically want to execute."One of the key benefits here is there is no upgrade required. You can do it all right now. And you don‚Äôt have to use it if you don‚Äôt want to: "This is opt-in. If you don‚Äôt trust your coins being locked to some Turing complete contract (totally reasonable) then don‚Äôt lock them to a Turing complete smart contract." - Sam ParkerSince there will be some computational limits on what you can do, I think the lowest hanging fruit for something like BitVM is replacing a lot of the centralized ‚ÄúBitcoin edge‚Äù services that people currently use.For example we could "cut out all kinds of trusted or semi-trusted escrow services that a version of Bitcoin without this requires. Congestion control/Coinjoin aggregators, sidechain quorums, certain types of DLC oracles, all can go from trusted/semi-trusted to 100% trustless. Bitcoin‚Äôs trustlessness is only as strong as the weakest link in the interaction you are engaging in with it." - Sam ParkerNow let‚Äôs get into what Eric Wall thinks about it:""I just read the whitepaper and all the concepts check out to me. I have a natural disinclination for schemes that require very large pre-signed transaction exchanges in a setup phase‚ÄîI don‚Äôt know which issues may arise from such schemes. Overhead and permission are the two big issues. For now, I‚Äôm cautiously excited, waiting for what the real-world experiments will yield. Maybe there are elegant, trivial solutions to the two-party limitations of this scheme, maybe there aren‚Äôt. Maybe the overhead is manageable for specific types of computation, like zk proofs. If BitVM works well to verify a zk proof inside it, then that‚Äôs interesting‚ÄîBitVM would then serve the role of the zkwasm layer [I‚Äôve discussed previously]."" - Eric WallHe then continued with what is probably the best succinct summary of BitVM:"Is it correct to say that BitVM today only describes a way by which a verifier can steal a bond from a prover depending on the outcome of a turing complete computation, but doesn‚Äôt really describe an architecture for peg-in/outs for outside participants?"The answer to his question is yes, this is exactly what BitVM is at this point.Adam Back jumped in with a more critical comment (that has tons of views) "For people getting (over) excited, this is cool but effectively a generalization of a two-party game - it says right in the abstract - so it's a bit like Greg Maxwell's 2016 ZKP contingent payments implemented example".Except Adam missed a part of the paper and this BitVM is actually strictly better than Greg Maxwell‚Äôs 2016 ZKP example. Quote from Robin: "It is strictly superior [than Greg Maxwell‚Äôs 2016 ZKP example because] in a ZKCP the prover has to know the solution upfront."Super Testnet was a reviewer on the article and posted: "This is probably the most exciting discovery in the history of bitcoin script. It seems to knock down practically every door, and gives us access to covenants, sidechains, and powers similar to Liquid or the EVM, all at once with no forks required. I can't wait to publish my demo."And to answer Eric Wall‚Äôs question about 1 to N party setups, Super Testnet posted: ‚ÄúIt also allows for 1-N parties, similar to rollups. You can have a central party take a fee to perform computations for a group. Everyone in the group knows the central party cannot lie or the group can take, and distribute among themselves, a massive bond."So some additional trust, but with nice economic trust assumptions as the central party loses in the event that they are dishonest.One main downside to BitVM is the complexity. There is a lot of presigning that needs to occur in order for BitVM to work.Rijndael commented: "Seems like CTV would cut down on the presigning. This would be great to build with current bitcoin and then figure out how much interactivity could be cut out with ctv and whether thats a nice to have or a must have".If you aren‚Äôt up to speed here, CTV = BIP-119 = Simple Covenants. So if we upgraded Bitcoin to enable CTV, BitVM would be a lot nicer and more efficient.Post Capone added his own take on the current positivity across many ecosystems within Bitcoin: "BitVM has spurred net positive commentary from 8 separate legions within bitcoin that notoriously slander each other into oblivion. Big stuff, man. Big stuff. Hats off to a lot of the analysis/feedback that has been piped out in such short order. It's very cool to see. Ordinals was a magical moment. This feels like it has the gas in the tank to double down on that. We're all clamoring over ourselves to hack it into working order."BitVM is very similar to Lightning Network as (at least in the paper) there is a 2:2 multisig requirement.Dylan LeClair posted: "Correct me if wrong: although technically much different, its like LN in the sense that it's a 2:2 multisig where TXs/apps/contracts can be built above bitcoin, but verification & settlement occurs on-chain. As I understand it this would enable trustless BTC peg-ins (?)".To which Sam replied: "It enables basically anything you‚Äôd want to enable including trustless peg ins. It‚Äôs very similar in spirit to lightning in that way yes. I think running this protocol inside of a lightning channel is going to be the real power play personally. I suspect there‚Äôs a way to piggyback on Lightning‚Äôs justice transactions in a very synergistic way."Some have doubted whether BitVM can support a global state due to the state-channel-like description in the article, but Super Testnet responded "It supports global state. Party A can prove statements to party B about a global ledger such as bitcoin or a sidechain or even an alt-chain."Essentially BitVM ‚Äúenables more expressive Bitcoin contracts. Particularly, it enables functionality that we thought we'd need a soft fork for. It might enable trustless sidechains, but that's not fully solved yet." - Super TestnetAnd Rijndale responded that we likely still need covenants for trustless sidechains: ‚ÄúBitVM lets you spend ALL of a UTXO with a smart contract. For trustless sidechains we need to be able to spend PART of a UTXO with a smart contract".Bob's take:1. Another whitepaper, another round of podcasts, and another loop around the sun. BitVM is very interesting, but it is still in the research phase with much still to be explored, so TBD on how many problems BitVM can solve for us all.2. There are likely some simple key use cases that could start leveraging BitVM right now to reduce trust assumptions (DLC oracles).3. We need a variety of different paths to give us additional programmability on Bitcoin, so I applaud anyone working on solutions in this area (BitVM included). I hope tons of devs build really cool demos with it that solve big problems for people.Thanks for reading! If I missed anything, please correct me or ask questions in the replies.Quelle: https://twitter.com/BobBodily/status/1711581484254192013

comments.body: Bei BitVM gab es dieses Jahr sehr spannende neue Entwicklungen, die besonders f√ºr mein Lieblingsthema "Sidechains" (Layer 2) ziemlich relevant sind. Ich kann gar nicht verstehen, dass im englischen Forumsteil kaum dar√ºber gesprochen wird.Im April hat Linus die zweite Version BitVM 2 und daf√ºr Whitepaper und Anwendungsszenarien ver√∂ffentlicht. BitVM2 enth√§lt wesentliche Verbesserungen, so k√∂nnen Vertr√§ge zwischen mehr als zwei Parteien abgeschlossen werden. Damit werden endlich dezentralisierte Bridges/Sidechains m√∂glich, ohne dass neue Opcodes z.B. f√ºr Covenants ben√∂tigt werden (Covenants sind Bedingungen, die f√ºr transferierbare Bitcoins aufgestellt werden k√∂nnen, also z.B. dass man einen Bitcoin zwar weiterversenden darf, aber nur wenn ein Teil davon an Adresse X gespendet wird. Das geht mit dem heutigen Bitcoin Script nicht.). Denn die Covenants k√∂nnen somit "simuliert" werden.F√ºr diese "Simulationen" in BitVM2 sind allerdings riesige Programme in Gigabyte-Gr√∂√üe notwendig. So ein "Prover" f√ºr Zero Knowledge Proofs (Groth16) mit 2,9 GB ...Alles h√∂chst kompliziert und ich m√∂chte mir gar nicht rausnehmen als Nicht-Informatiker da allzu viel von zu verstehen au√üer den absoluten Grundlagen ...Eine Linkliste gibt es hier bei Github. Es gibt auch schon Sidechain-Designs, wie das vor kurzem hier vorgestellte BitSync (der Thread dar√ºber ist der Anlass, warum ich mich endlich mal mit BitVM befasst habe und diesen Faden auf der Versenkung hole).Ob es ein Altcoin-Killer wird? Ich glaube, BitVM ist wegen seiner sehr hohen Komplexit√§t eher keine Konkurrenz zu Ethereum. F√ºr ein DeFi-Team wird es einfacher und weniger riskant sein, ihr Design auf ETH zu implementieren. F√ºr Anwendungsf√§lle, die Bitcoin skalierbarer machen, also Layer-2s, dagegen k√∂nnte sich BitVM gut eignen.
